title: #YaNasty: WWE wrestler pulls stunt and Mountie plays along
text:
Video has more than 2.5 million views on Twitter

When American WWE wrestler Lacey Evans was pulled over for speeding outside of Edmonton on Saturday, she didn’t hold back with her catchphrase.

“You nasty thing,” she yelled at the Mountie who handed her the ticket.

At least, that’s how the interaction came across in a video posted to her Twitter account that afternoon.

Turns out, while the ticket was real, the “nasty” tone of the interaction was staged.

1.Canada is terrible.����

2. You know Exactly who I am.

3. You will be speaking to my lawyer. ���� #YaNasty pic.twitter.com/EsqRSaj4iV — Lacey Evans ~ WWE Superstar (@LaceyEvansWWE) September 21, 2019

At first, Evans “engaged in a courteous and polite conversation” with the officer, according to a press release from the RCMP in Alberta.

Then she asked if he would “participate in a rehearsed interaction on camera with her WWE persona,” the RCMP said.

“The member obliged.”

It took a few days for the news to surface that the conversation was fake.

In the meantime, Evans played it up on her Twitter feed.

“Have a good day,” the officer is heard saying in the video.

“You have a terrible day, sir,” she said. “Canada is terrible.”

“Welcome to Edmonton,” the Mountie said in response as he waved and walked away.

At first, some Canadians took to Twitter to voice their disgust with her behaviour.

Many also talked about how “Canadian” it was of the officer to keep his cool, despite the trash-talking.

Eventually, some people started to catch on...

And when the news came out that it was all for the sake of entertainment, some people took to Twitter to admit they’d been duped.

RCMP spokesperson Fraser Logan said as far as he knows, the officer didn’t get into trouble for playing along.

"RCMP members, whenever they are out there in the community, they will definitely oblige any request from the public that they deem is appropriate."

Setting the record straight

On Sept. 23, Evans posted a note on Twitter saying she doesn’t want anybody out there thinking it’s OK to disrespect a law enforcement officer.

She said her job is to entertain, but also to set a good example, and as a former U.S. Marine and military police officer, she wanted to set the record straight.

“I’m glad you all were entertained,” she said, “but if you ever try to honestly disrespect or put my brothers and sisters in blue in harm … I hope you get what you ask for.”

With files from the Canadian Press
description: When WWE wrestler Lacey Evans trash-talked an Alberta RCMP officer during a traffic stop, he was polite. Turns out, it was staged.
